name: CountdownTimer
comment:
A simple countdown timer that fires events in regular increments until a duration has passed.

CountdownTimer implements quiver/quiver-async.Stream and sends itself as the event. From the timer you can get the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.remaining and quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.elapsed time, or quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.cancel the timer.

constructors.comment:
Creates a new quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer that fires events in increments of quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.CountdownTimer-.increment, until the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.CountdownTimer-.duration has passed.

quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.CountdownTimer-.stopwatch and quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.CountdownTimer-.createTimerPeriodic are for testing purposes. If you're using CountdownTimer and need to control time in a test, pass mocks or fakes. See FakeTimer and FakeStopwatch.

listen.name: listen
listen.comment:
Adds a subscription to this stream.

On each data event from this stream, the subscriber's quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onData handler is called. If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onData is null, nothing happens.

On errors from this stream, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError handler is given a object describing the error.

The quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError accepts two arguments it is called with the stack trace (which could be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace). Otherwise it is called with just the error object.

If this stream closes, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onDone handler is called.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.cancelOnError is true, the subscription is ended when the first error is reported. The default is false.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

isBroadcast.name: isBroadcast
isBroadcast.comment: Reports whether this stream is a broadcast stream.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment:
Reports whether this stream contains any elements.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

first.name: first
first.comment:
Returns the first element of the stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

Except for the type of the error, this method is equivalent to this.elementAt(0).

last.name: last
last.comment:
Returns the last element of the stream.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

single.name: single
single.comment:
Returns the single element.

If an error event occurs before or after the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this is empty or has more than one element throws a dart-core.StateError.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

asBroadcastStream.name: asBroadcastStream
asBroadcastStream.comment:
Returns a multi-subscription stream that produces the same events as this.

If this stream is already a broadcast stream, it is returned unmodified.

If this stream is single-subscription, return a new stream that allows multiple subscribers. It will subscribe to this stream when its first subscriber is added, and will stay subscribed until this stream ends, or a callback cancels the subscription.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asBroadcastStream.onListen is provided, it is called with a subscription-like object that represents the underlying subscription to this stream. It is possible to pause, resume or cancel the subscription during the call to quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asBroadcastStream.onListen. It is not possible to change the event handlers, including using quiver/dart-async.StreamSubscription.asFuture.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asBroadcastStream.onCancel is provided, it is called in a similar way to quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asBroadcastStream.onListen when the returned stream stops having listener. If it later gets a new listener, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asBroadcastStream.onListen function is called again.

Use the callbacks, for example, for pausing the underlying subscription while having no subscribers to prevent losing events, or canceling the subscription when there are no listeners.

listen.name: listen
listen.comment:
Adds a subscription to this stream.

On each data event from this stream, the subscriber's quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onData handler is called. If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onData is null, nothing happens.

On errors from this stream, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError handler is given a object describing the error.

The quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onError accepts two arguments it is called with the stack trace (which could be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace). Otherwise it is called with just the error object.

If this stream closes, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.onDone handler is called.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.listen.cancelOnError is true, the subscription is ended when the first error is reported. The default is false.

where.name: where
where.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that discards some data events.

The new stream sends the same error and done events as this stream, but it only sends the data events that satisfy the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.where.test.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

map.name: map
map.comment:
Creates a new stream that converts each element of this stream to a new value using the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.map.convert function.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

asyncMap.name: asyncMap
asyncMap.comment:
Creates a new stream with each data event of this stream asynchronously mapped to a new event.

This acts like quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.map, except that quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asyncMap.convert may return a quiver/dart-async.Future, and in that case, the stream waits for that future to complete before continuing with its result.

asyncExpand.name: asyncExpand
asyncExpand.comment:
Creates a new stream with the events of a stream per original event.

This acts like quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.expand, except that quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asyncExpand.convert returns a quiver/quiver-async.Stream instead of an dart-core.Iterable. The events of the returned stream becomes the events of the returned stream, in the order they are produced.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.asyncExpand.convert returns null, no value is put on the output stream, just as if it returned an empty stream.

handleError.name: handleError
handleError.comment:
Creates a wrapper Stream that intercepts some errors from this stream.

If this stream sends an error that matches quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.handleError.test, then it is intercepted by the handle function.

The quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.handleError.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). Depending on the function type the the stream either invokes quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.handleError.onError with or without a stack trace. The stack trace argument might be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace.

An asynchronous error e is matched by a test function if test(e) returns true. If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.handleError.test is omitted, every error is considered matching.

If the error is intercepted, the handle function can decide what to do with it. It can throw if it wants to raise a new (or the same) error, or simply return to make the stream forget the error.

If you need to transform an error into a data event, use the more generic quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.transform to handle the event by writing a data event to the output sink

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

expand.name: expand
expand.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that converts each element into zero or more events.

Each incoming event is converted to an dart-core.Iterable of new events, and each of these new events are then sent by the returned stream in order.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

pipe.name: pipe
pipe.comment: Binds this stream as the input of the provided quiver/dart-async.StreamConsumer.

transform.name: transform
transform.comment:
Chains this stream as the input of the provided quiver/dart-async.StreamTransformer.

Returns the result of streamTransformer.bind itself.

reduce.name: reduce
reduce.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.reduce.combine.

fold.name: fold
fold.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.fold.combine.

join.name: join
join.comment:
Collects string of data events' string representations.

If quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.join.separator is provided, it is inserted between any two elements.

Any error in the stream causes the future to complete with that error. Otherwise it completes with the collected string when the "done" event arrives.

contains.name: contains
contains.comment:
Checks whether quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.contains.needle occurs in the elements provided by this stream.

Completes the quiver/dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the quiver/dart-async.Future will report that error.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Executes quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.forEach.action on each data event of the stream.

Completes the returned quiver/dart-async.Future when all events of the stream have been processed. Completes the future with an error if the stream has an error event, or if quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.forEach.action throws.

every.name: every
every.comment:
Checks whether quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.every.test accepts all elements provided by this stream.

Completes the quiver/dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the quiver/dart-async.Future will report that error.

any.name: any
any.comment:
Checks whether quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.any.test accepts any element provided by this stream.

Completes the quiver/dart-async.Future when the answer is known.

If this stream reports an error, the quiver/dart-async.Future reports that error.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been found.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after this element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

toList.name: toList
toList.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.List.

toSet.name: toSet
toSet.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.Set.

drain.name: drain
drain.comment:
Discards all data on the stream, but signals when it's done or an error occured.

When subscribing using quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.drain, cancelOnError will be true. This means that the future will complete with the first error on the stream and then cancel the subscription.

In case of a done event the future completes with the given quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.drain.futureValue.

take.name: take
take.comment:
Provides at most the first n values of this stream.

Forwards the first n data events of this stream, and all error events, to the returned stream, and ends with a done event.

If this stream produces fewer than quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.take.count values before it's done, so will the returned stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first n elements have been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

takeWhile.name: takeWhile
takeWhile.comment:
Forwards data events while quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.takeWhile.test is successful.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream as long as quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.takeWhile.test returns true for the event data. The stream is done when either this stream is done, or when this stream first provides a value that quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.takeWhile.test doesn't accept.

Stops listening to the stream after the accepted elements.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skip.name: skip
skip.comment:
Skips the first quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.skip.count data events from this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skipWhile.name: skipWhile
skipWhile.comment:
Skip data events from this stream while they are matched by quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.skipWhile.test.

Error and done events are provided by the returned stream unmodified.

Starting with the first data event where quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.skipWhile.test returns false for the event data, the returned stream will have the same events as this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

distinct.name: distinct
distinct.comment:
Skips data events if they are equal to the previous data event.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream, except that it never provides two consequtive data events that are equal.

Equality is determined by the provided quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.distinct.equals method. If that is omitted, the '==' operator on the last provided data element is used.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

firstWhere.name: firstWhere
firstWhere.comment:
Finds the first element of this stream matching quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere.test.

Returns a future that is filled with the first element of this stream that quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere.test returns true for.

If no such element is found before this stream is done, and a quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere.defaultValue function is provided, the result of calling quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere.defaultValue becomes the value of the future.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element that matches the predicate. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error occurs, or if this stream ends without finding a match and with no quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere.defaultValue function provided, the future will receive an error.

lastWhere.name: lastWhere
lastWhere.comment:
Finds the last element in this stream matching quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.lastWhere.test.

As quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.firstWhere, except that the last matching element is found. That means that the result cannot be provided before this stream is done.

singleWhere.name: singleWhere
singleWhere.comment:
Finds the single element in this stream matching quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.singleWhere.test.

Like lastMatch, except that it is an error if more than one matching element occurs in the stream.

elementAt.name: elementAt
elementAt.comment:
Returns the value of the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.elementAt.indexth data event of this stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.elementAt.indexth data event has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with this error.

If a done event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with a dart-core.RangeError.

timeout.name: timeout
timeout.comment:
Creates a new stream with the same events as this stream.

Whenever more than quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.timeout.timeLimit passes between two events from this stream, the quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.timeout.onTimeout function is called.

The countdown doesn't start until the returned stream is listened to. The countdown is reset every time an event is forwarded from this stream, or when the stream is paused and resumed.

The quiver/quiver-async.CountdownTimer.timeout.onTimeout function is called with one argument: an quiver/dart-async.EventSink that allows putting events into the returned stream. This EventSink is only valid during the call to onTimeout.

If onTimeout is omitted, a timeout will just put a quiver/dart-async.TimeoutException into the error channel of the returned stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.
